meanings.def: to move quickly off the ground or away from a surface by pushing yourself with your legs and feet
examples: ‘Quick, jump!’ he shouted.
jump + adv./prep. She jumped into the water to save them.
He jumped into the air and started cheering.
She jumped down from the chair.
The children were jumping up and down with excitement.
The pilot jumped from the burning plane (= with a parachute).
He killed himself by jumping off a bridge.
jump + noun She has jumped 2.2 metres.
He tried to jump back on board.
She jumped up onto the table.
Stop jumping on the furniture!
They all jumped for joy and hugged each other.
The dog kept jumping up at me.

meanings.def: to pass over something by jumping
examples: jump over something He jumped over the wall to get away.
jump something Can you jump that gate?
He jumped the stream and carried on up the hill.
His horse fell as it jumped the last hurdle.
jump something over something I jumped my horse over all the fences.

meanings.def: to move quickly and suddenly
examples: He jumped to his feet when they called his name.
She jumped up and ran out of the room.
Do you want a ride? Jump in.
He jumped out of the car and disappeared into the building.
When she heard the news, she immediately jumped on a plane to France.

meanings.def: to make a sudden movement because of surprise, fear or excitement
examples: A loud bang made me jump.
Her heart jumped when she heard the news.
He crept up behind me and made me jump.
She jumped slightly at the sound of the bell.

meanings.def: to rise suddenly by a large amount
examples: jump by… Prices jumped by 60% last year.
jump (from…) (to…) Sales jumped from $2.7 billion to $3.5 billion.
Your interest rate might suddenly jump at the end of the fixed period.
jump + noun The FTSE 100 benchmark index jumped 199.9 points.
Profits jumped by 15 per cent during the year.
Shares jumped from 2p to 222p.

meanings.def: to change suddenly from one subject to another
examples: I couldn't follow the talk because he kept jumping about from one topic to another.
The story then jumps from her childhood in New York to her first visit to London.

meanings.def: to leave out something and pass to a further point or stage
examples: You seem to have jumped several steps in the argument.

meanings.def: to move suddenly and unexpectedly, especially out of the correct position
examples: The needle jumped across the dial.

meanings.def: to attack somebody suddenly
examples: The thieves jumped him in a dark alleyway.

meanings.def: to get on a vehicle very quickly, especially in a way that is dangerous or illegal
examples: to jump a bus

meanings.def: to start the engine of a car by connecting the battery to the battery of another car with jump leads
to put a lot of energy into starting a process or an activity or into making it start more quickly
to be very lively
examples: The bar's jumping tonight.

meanings.def: to be very angry or excited about something
examples: The local residents are jumping up and down complaining about the noise.

meanings.def: to join others in doing something that is becoming fashionable because you hope to become popular or successful yourself
examples: politicians eager to jump on the environmental bandwagon

meanings.def: to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial
examples: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

meanings.def: to start or be made to start a new and difficult activity that you are not prepared for
examples: Junior hospital doctors are thrown in at the deep end in their first jobs.
The company believes in throwing new employees in at the deep end with no training.

meanings.def: to react very angrily to somebody
to do something too soon, before the right time
to fail to stop at a red traffic light
to move violently because of a sudden shock
examples: She nearly jumped out of her skin when she saw me.

meanings.def: to go to the front of a line of people without waiting for your turn
examples: She jumped the queue at the ticket counter.
(figurative) Because he had money, he was able to jump the queue and get treatment that was not available to other people.

meanings.def: to leave the track suddenly
(used especially about a television series, etc.) to include something that is very hard to believe as an attempt to keep people watching, usually a sign that the show is not as good as it used to be
examples: Has the show finally jumped the shark?

meanings.def: to leave the ship on which you are serving, without permission
to leave an organization that you belong to, suddenly and unexpectedly
to do something difficult or complicated in order to achieve something
examples: You have to jump through so many hoops to get a job like this.

meanings.def: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.
Don't jump to conclusions.
We don't want to jump to the wrong conclusion.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to hurry and do something quickly

idioms.def: to be very angry or excited about something
examples: The local residents are jumping up and down complaining about the noise.

idioms.def: to join others in doing something that is becoming fashionable because you hope to become popular or successful yourself
examples: politicians eager to jump on the environmental bandwagon

idioms.def: to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial
examples: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

idioms.idiom: jump/be thrown in at the deep end
idioms.def: to start or be made to start a new and difficult activity that you are not prepared for
examples: Junior hospital doctors are thrown in at the deep end in their first jobs.
The company believes in throwing new employees in at the deep end with no training.

idioms.def: to react very angrily to somebody
to do something too soon, before the right time
to fail to stop at a red traffic light
to move violently because of a sudden shock
examples: She nearly jumped out of her skin when she saw me.

idioms.def: to go to the front of a line of people without waiting for your turn
examples: She jumped the queue at the ticket counter.
(figurative) Because he had money, he was able to jump the queue and get treatment that was not available to other people.

idioms.def: (used especially about a television series, etc.) to include something that is very hard to believe as an attempt to keep people watching, usually a sign that the show is not as good as it used to be
examples: Has the show finally jumped the shark?

idioms.def: to leave the ship on which you are serving, without permission
to do something difficult or complicated in order to achieve something
examples: You have to jump through so many hoops to get a job like this.

idioms.idiom: jump/leap to conclusions | jump/leap to the conclusion that…
idioms.def: to make a decision about somebody/something too quickly, before you know or have thought about all the facts
examples: There I go again—jumping to conclusions.
Don't jump to conclusions.
We don't want to jump to the wrong conclusion.

idioms.def: used to tell somebody to hurry and do something quickly

meanings.def: an act of jumping
examples: to do a parachute jump
jump of… a jump of over six metres
jump from something Somehow he survived the jump from the third floor of the building.
She managed a jump of 1.6 metres.
Cats can clear six feet with a standing jump.
She made a jump for the river bank.

meanings.def: a barrier like a narrow fence that a horse or a runner has to jump over in a race or competition
examples: The horse fell at the last jump.

meanings.def: a sudden increase in amount, price or value
examples: unusually large price jumps
jump in something a 20 per cent jump in pre-tax profits
The sportswear company reports a jump in sales since the Olympics.
There's been no sudden jump, but a steady increase year on year.

meanings.def: a large or sudden change
examples: Is he good enough to make the jump into Formula One?
The story takes a jump back in time.
The negotiations took a jump forward yesterday (= they made progress).
The new law is a jump into the unknown.

meanings.def: a sudden movement caused by shock or surprise
examples: I sat up with a jump.
Her heart gave a little jump at his smile.

meanings.def: to be going to be severely punished
examples: If I catch you cheating, you’ll be for the high jump.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody in a rude way to go away
examples: Why didn’t you just tell him to take a running jump?

meanings.def: to keep your advantage over somebody, especially your competitors, by taking action before they do or by making sure you know more than they do

idioms.def: to be going to be severely punished
examples: If I catch you cheating, you’ll be for the high jump.

idioms.def: used to tell somebody in a rude way to go away
examples: Why didn’t you just tell him to take a running jump?

idioms.idiom: to keep, etc. one jump ahead (of somebody)
idioms.def: to keep your advantage over somebody, especially your competitors, by taking action before they do or by making sure you know more than they do
